title: Lincoln's Election & Secession
subtitle: The Union Breaks (1860-1861)

sections.title: The Election of 1860
sections.summary: I'm William, fifteen years old, from Charleston, South Carolina. The presidential election of 1860 has our city in turmoil. Father says this election will determine whether we remain in the Union or leave it.

sections.title: Lincoln Wins—The South Reacts
sections.summary: November 6, 1860. Election results arrive by telegraph. Abraham Lincoln has won the presidency.

sections.title: The Confederacy Forms
sections.summary: South Carolina's secession triggers a chain reaction. Within weeks, six more states of the Deep South follow: Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, and Texas. All cite Lincoln's election and Northern hostility to slavery as reasons for leaving.

sections.title: The Fort Sumter Crisis
sections.summary: Charleston Harbor, March 1861. Fort Sumter, a federal fort on an island in our harbor, remains under Union control. Major Robert Anderson commands about 80 U.S.

sections.title: The Nation Chooses Sides
sections.summary: April 15, 1861. President Lincoln responds to Fort Sumter's fall by calling for 75,000 volunteers to suppress the rebellion. He's calling us rebels.
